title: Rescue after scaffolding collapse at old Panmure Bridge, Auckland
text:
Rescue after scaffolding collapse at old Panmure Bridge, Auckland Last updated 15:14, February 21 2017 
A man was trapped by the fallen scaffolding, and was rescued by the fire service's high angle rescue team. 
A man who witnessed a scaffolding collapse in Auckland has described the sight of bodies falling into the water as the structure "unzipped" before him. 
On Tuesday morning, three people were taken to hospital with moderate and minor injuries after scaffolding they were working on collapsed in the East Auckland suburb of Panmure. 
One of the men was trapped against the Panmure Bridge and had to be freed by emergency services who cordoned off the scene. NZN VIDEO 
Dramatic rescue after scaffold collapse in Panmure, Auckland. 
Fire station officer Frank Walsh said six people ended up in the water and a man was trapped on the underside of the bridge after the incident at 10am. 
The man was rescued by the fire service's high angle rescue team. 
The rescued man seemed unfazed by the drama. CATRIN OWEN/ FAIRFAX NZ 
The scaffolding collapsed underneath the Panmure Bridge. 
He drummed his hands against the bridge as he waited for help, then shook hands with his rescuers. 
Roger Hill, a yacht designer based at the Panmure Bridge Marina, was sitting about 30 metres away when the collapse happened. 
Hill was sitting at his desk when he heard a loud noise. CATRIN OWEN/ FAIRFAX NZ 
Collapsed scaffolding beneath Panmure Bridge. 
"I looked up and it just started collapsing from the Panmure end and I saw it start unzipping to the Pakuranga Rd end. 
"It folded and twisted into the river, and the people on it were falling into the water and were banging on things as they came down," Hill said. 
He said a pipe connected to the bridge, holding the scaffolding in place broke off. NZN VIDEO 
Station Officer Frank Walsh speaks about rescue efforts after a scaffold collapse on the Old Panmure Bridge in Auckland. 
"The whole thing unzipped, it was literally like dominos." 
Hill said the workers have been putting up the scaffolding progressively as they work across the bridge. 
Witnesses told 1News the scaffolding collapse sounded "like a plane was landing". 1 NEWS 
The collapse at the old Panmure Bridge left four people in the water. 
St John spokesman Mark Deoki said one patient in a moderate condition and two patients with minor injuries were taken to Middlemore Hospital. 
Another patient was being assessed at an accident and medical centre. 
It was hard to determine exactly how the scaffolding collapsed, he said. CATRIN OWEN/FAIRFAX NZ 
Collapsed scaffolding in the lagoon beneath Panmure Bridge. 
The bridge remained open to traffic. 
It is understood the bridge was undergoing paint and concrete repairs. 
WorkSafe spokesman Chris Baylis said the organisation had been notified and was making initial inquiries. 
New Zealand's voluntary industry association for scaffolding is Scaffolding Access and Rigging New Zealand. 
Its chief executive Graham Burke said he was aware of the incident and it would be thoroughly investigated. 
"It's a long time since we've had an incident like this in New Zealand and I think that's a reflection that we have a very professional industry," Burke said. 
Scaffolding was an industry with the potential for harm every day, he said. 
Burke said a full investigation would be carried out. 
"If there's lessons to be learnt, they will" he said. 
A Middlemore spokeswoman said all three hospitalised men seemed to be fine and were awaiting further assessment. - Stuff
